intro: Chorizanthe ventricosa, commonly known as the woolly cholla, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its spiny, cylindrical stems covered in a dense layer of white, waxy hairs. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in clusters during the spring and summer months. Its adaptations to arid environments include reduced leaf surfaces and extensive root systems for water retention. Chorizanthe ventricosa is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various insects and small animals.
